entry.title: Merge pull request #4022 from bk2204/verify-releases
entry.content:
Merge pull request #4022 from bk2204/verify-releases

README: explain how to verify releases

entry.title: README: explain how to verify releases
entry.content:
README: explain how to verify releases

Some folks aren't familiar with the signed SHA-256 sums file we use, or
aren't sure how to get the keys to verify releases.  To help them, point
them to the tag we've created that contains the keys (similar to the way
Git does this) and add an explanation to the README to help them verify
the releases.

entry.title: Merge pull request #4026 from bk2204/linux-no-cgo
entry.content:
Merge pull request #4026 from bk2204/linux-no-cgo

Stop using cgo on amd64 Linux

entry.title: .github/workflows: disable cgo when building on Linux
entry.content:
.github/workflows: disable cgo when building on Linux

In the previous commit, we removed the need for building with cgo on
Linux.  However, Go still wants to link against glibc by default,
probably due to support for the name service switch.  This makes our
binaries not work on musl-based systems, however.

Since we already build the RPMs without cgo, it's likely that nobody
actually cares about support for the small number of resolver features
we'd be missing, so explicitly build with cgo when building binaries in
workflows.  Note that any binaries built on amd64 Linux for other
platforms (whether Linux or not) are already not using cgo, since
they're cross-compiled and we wouldn't have the appropriate compilers or
libcs available to support cgo anyway, so this only affects the amd64
binaries we produce.

entry.title: tools: remove the use of cgo on Linux
entry.content:
tools: remove the use of cgo on Linux

We currently import the C package solely for a single value: the FICLONE
ioctl, which is a constant.  Since this is a constant and also part of
the Linux kernel ABI, there's no reason we need to have the C compiler
generate it for us every time we build.  We can instead hard-code the
constant in place, since it will never change.

This avoids the need for cgo in order to have a functional invocation of
git lfs dedup on Linux.

entry.title: docs: document git lfs migrate --yes
entry.content:
docs: document git lfs migrate --yes

We've long had the option "--yes" to migrate noninteractively, but have
never documented it.  Document what it does, and warn users that
reckless use may cause data loss to avoid potential user sadness.

entry.title: Merge branch 'master' into cherry-pick-panic
entry.content: Merge branch 'master' into cherry-pick-panic

entry.title: commands: avoid send on closed channel on 'delay'
entry.content:
commands: avoid send on closed channel on 'delay'

Fix 'panic: send on closed channel' when cherry-pick several commits.
The issue occurs when LFS files of cherry-picked commits do not
exist in LFS cache. The first smudge command closes incoming channel
of TransferQueue and never opens it again. Resolve issue by creating
TransferQueue each 'smudge' command.

entry.title: Check error when creating local storage directory
entry.content:
Check error when creating local storage directory

When we have an error creating the local storage directory, such as if
the permissions are wrong, we fail to produce a helpful error message,
since we fail to check the error we produce.

Let's take the error we get in such a case and pass it through to the
transfer queue, where we can handle it as any other error.  This means
that if only one directory has a problem, we can transfer the rest of
the objects and fail for only the one problematic object.

entry.title: Merge pull request #4009 from bk2204/large-file-warning
entry.content:
Merge pull request #4009 from bk2204/large-file-warning

Add an option to control warning about files larger than 4 GiB

entry.title: Add an option to control warning about files larger than 4 GiB
entry.content:
Add an option to control warning about files larger than 4 GiB

Git on Windows is currently incapable of handling files larger than 4
GiB in size.  This is because Git uses "unsigned long" for numerous
types of variables representing files, which on a Unix system is an
appropriate way to specify a pointer-sized integer, since Unix systems
are either ILP32 or LP64.  However, Windows is LLP64, meaning that a
variable of type unsigned long is always 32 bits.

We warn about this case to help alert users to potential corruption when
they're working across platforms.  However, there are some users and
projects who don't use Windows and therefore don't have this problem.
For those users and projects, this warning is not helpful.  Let's add
an option to control that warning so folks who don't wish to see it can
disable it.

entry.title: Merge pull request #4000 from bk2204/track-filename-already-supported
entry.content:
Merge pull request #4000 from bk2204/track-filename-already-supported

track: detect duplicate patterns with --filename

entry.title: track: detect duplicate patterns with --filename
entry.content:
track: detect duplicate patterns with --filename

When we add a pattern with git lfs track, we inform the user if the
pattern is already supported.  However, we fail to do so when the
--filename argument is passed, due to not having encoded the pattern at
that point.

To solve this problem, hoist the code that encodes the filename as a
pattern so it happens before we check if we already have such a pattern.
